One theme, Harry, of which I am increasingly aware is the new
problem of coptinuitv in a world of accelerating change.
Drucker points out that in the business world the awareness
that technicological change could put them , any of them, out
of action in afew years has led to capital investment in
research as by far the heaviest item of expenditure. In other
words, don't wait for change, rather become change and control
it from wi thin.
Now educationally our idea of positional ”warfare” is as
obsolete as the assembly-line, or delegated authority structures
(cf. Drucker, p.96). We shal 1 have to institutionalize
change educationally just as Business has done. And this
means spending ,perhaps, ten times our total present budgets
on research. We must effect a means of continuous transition
at all levels and in all age groups simultaneously. So that
we must abolish our present idea of education as that done for
the voung. In our kind of electric technology education becomes
inclusive of all ages and all interests. The global community
of learning can be nothing less than that literally. For
hundreds of years we have gloried in the discontinuities and
destruction caused in society an^ *ts institutions by innovation.
In the age of simultaneity this becomes intolerable.
